Clive has a set of ten cubes of side length 1, 2, 3, ..., 10 \text{ cm} respectively. He wants to make a closed rectangular chest in which to keep them all.

a. Show that the volume of the chest must be at least $3025 \text{ cm}^3$.
b. Show that the volume of the chest need not be more than $4400 \text{ cm}^3$ if all the cubes are placed on the bottom of the chest.

Clive can put all the cubes in a 19 cm\times17 cm\times13 cm chest by placing the 10, 9, 8, 7 cubes on the bottom of the chest, then the 3, 4, 5, 6 cubes on top of these respectively, and finally fitting the 1 and 2 cubes in the remaining space. This is demonstrated in the diagram on the left which shows a top view, with the bottom of the chest indicated by shading. A packing such as this is called \textit{tight} because none of the chest dimensions can be decreased with the cubes in their same relative positions. The diagram on the right shows a non-tight packing.

Suppose the 3-digit number has the form *abc*. From the given properties we have

$$
(10c + b) - (10b + c) = 36 \quad (1)
$$

$$
(100a + c) - (100c - a) = 198 \quad (2)
$$

From (1) we get $9(c-b) = 36$, hence $c-b = 4$.

From (2) we get $99(a-c) = 198$, hence $a-c = 2$.

So $a-b = 6$.

Therefore $(100a+10b)-(100b+10a) = 90a-90b = 90(a-b) = \mathbf{540}$.

$3b^2 + 2b = 3 \times 12^3 + 1 \times 12^2 + 4 \times 12 = 5184 + 144 + 48 = 5376$.

*Method 1*

We have $3b^2 + 2b - 2^8 \times 3 \times 7 = 0$,

$(3b + 128)(b - 42) = 0,$

$b = \mathbf{42}.$

*Method 2*

We have $5376 \approx 3 \times b^2$. So $b^2 \approx 1792$, hence $b \approx 40$.

If $b = 40$, then $3b^2+2b = 3 \times 1600 + 2 \times 40 = 4800 + 80 = 4880 < 5376$.

If $b = 41$, then $3b^2+2b = 3 \times 1681 + 2 \times 41 = 5043 + 82 = 5125 < 5376$.

If $b = 42$, then $3b^2 + 2b = 3 \times 1764 + 2 \times 42 = 5292 + 84 = 5376$.

$b = \mathbf{42}.$

*Method 3*

Since 3 divides 5376 and $3b^2$, it also divides $2b$ and hence $b$.

Since 2 divides 5376 and $2b$, it also divides $3b^2$ and hence $b$.

Therefore 6 divides $b$ and we may substitute $b = 6c$ giving
$$3 \times 36c^2 + 12c = 5376, \quad 9c^2 + c = 448, \quad c(9c + 1) = 7 \times 64,$$
$$9c^2 + c - 7 \times 64 = 0.$$

Either testing $c = 1, 2, 3, \dots$ or factorising to $(9c + 64)(c - 7) = 0$ gives $c = 7$. Hence $b = \mathbf{42}$.

$$

For $x = y = 1, z = 0$, we obtain

$$
2f(1) + 2f(1) \geq 4f(1)^2 + 1,
$$

i.e. $0 \geq (2f(1) - 1)^2$, whence $f(1) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Conversely, the function $f$ defined by $f(x) = \frac{1}{2}$ for all $x$ satisfies the given inequality as can be seen by inspection.

### Solution 1

We have $\angle ADB = 180^\circ - \angle AC'B$ and $\angle ADC = 180^\circ - \angle AB'C$ since $AC'BD$ and $AB'CD$ are cyclic quadrilaterals.

Hence

$$
\angle BDC = 360^{\circ} - \angle ADB - \angle ADC = \angle AC'B + \angle AB'C = 180^{\circ} - \angle BA'C.
$$

It follows that $A'BDC$ is also a cyclic quadrilateral, so that $D$ lies on the circumcircles of $\triangle A'BC$, $\triangle AB'C$ and $\triangle ABC'$.

In particular, $O_A O_C$ and $O_B O_C$ bisect $\angle BOC$ and $\angle DO_C A$, respectively. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned} \angle O_A O_C O_B &= \angle O_A O_C D + \angle D O_C O_B \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \angle B O_C D + \frac{1}{2} \angle D O_C A \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \angle B O_C A \\ &= \angle A C' B . \end{aligned}
$$

**Solution 2** (Angelo Di Pasquale, Melbourne)

Points $O_A, O_B, O_C$ satisfy $AO_C = BO_C, BO_A = CO_A, CO_B = AO_B$ and in this problem $\angle AOCB + \angle BOAC + \angle COBA = 360^{\circ}$. Let $T_c$ be the rotation about $O_C$ which sends $A$ to $B$. Let $T_a$ be the rotation about $O_A$ which sends $B$ to $C$. Let $T_b$ be the rotation about $O_B$ which sends $C$ to $A$. The composition $T_b(T_a(T_c(\cdot)))$ of rotations is a translation since the angles of rotation add to $360^{\circ}$. Since, however, $T_b(T_a(T_c(A))) = A$, we can infer that the said composition $T_b(T_a(T_c(\cdot)))$ is, in fact, the identity transformation.

Consider what happens to the point $O_C$ under this composition. We have

$$
O_C \xrightarrow{T_c} O_C \xrightarrow{T_a} X \xrightarrow{T_b} O_C,
$$

where $X = T_a(O_C)$.

Solution by Yanning Xu, year 10, St Peter's College, SA.

\textbf{Case 1.} $a_1 = 0$. Then $a_2 = a_1a_3 = 0$. But this contradicts $a_1 + a_2 = 2010$.

\textbf{Case 2.} $a_2 = 0$. Then from $a_1 + a_2 = 2010$ we have $a_1 = 2010$.

Also $a_3 = a_2a_4 = 0a_4 = 0$. Then $a_4 = a_3a_5 = 0a_5 = 0$, and so on. In fact whenever we have $a_n = 0$, then we also have $a_{n+1} = a_na_{n+2} = 0a_{n+1} = 0$. Thus $a_n = 0$ for all $n \ge 2$. Hence our sequence is

$$
\begin{array}{lclcl}
a_1 & = & 2010 & & \\
a_2 & = & 0 & & \\
a_3 & = & 0 & & \\
a_4 & = & 0 & & \\\vdots & & & & \\
\end{array}
$$

It is easy to verify that this sequence satisfies the given properties.

$$
\text{Thus } a_{2011} + a_{2012} = 0 + 0 = 0.
$$

\textbf{Case 3.} $a_1 \neq 0$ and $a_2 \neq 0$. Write $a_1 = x$, $a_2 = y$ with $x, y \neq 0$. Note that $x + y = 2010$. Using $a_n = \frac{a_{n-1}}{a_{n-2}}$ for $n = 3, 4, \dots$, we compute

$$
\begin{array}{lclcl}
a_1 & = & x & & \\
a_2 & = & y & & \\
a_3 & = & \frac{y}{x} & & \\
a_4 & = & \frac{1}{x} & & \\
a_5 & = & \frac{1}{y} & & \\
a_6 & = & \frac{x}{y} & & \\
a_7 & = & x & & \\
a_8 & = & y & & \\\vdots & & & & \\
\end{array}
$$

Note that $a_1 = a_7$ and $a_2 = a_8$. Since the value of $a_n$ depends only on the values of $a_{n-1}$ and $a_{n-2}$ for $n \ge 3$, this means that we have entered a 6-cycle. Hence $a_n = a_{n+6}$ for all positive integers $n$. It is easy to verify that this 6-cycle satisfies the given properties for the sequence.

Thus since $2011 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ and $2012 \equiv 2 \pmod{6}$ it follows that $a_{2011} + a_{2012} = a_1 + a_2 = 2010$.

In conclusion we have shown that the only possible values for $a_{2011} + a_{2012}$ are 0 and 2010.

Solution by Sampson Wong, year 12, James Ruse Agricultural High School.

Refer to the diagram used in the second alternative. Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$ and $c = AB$. Our strategy is to compute $QS$ and $PR$ in terms of $a$, $b$, $c$.

Extend $BA$ past $A$ to a point $X$. Let $\angle BAC = \alpha$. Then $\angle CAS = 90^\circ - \alpha/2$ and also $\angle XAS = 180^\circ - (90^\circ - \alpha/2) - \alpha = 90^\circ - \alpha/2$. Thus $AS$ is the external bisector of $\angle BAC$. Hence by the angle bisector theorem applied to both the internal and external angle bisectors of $\angle BAC$ we have

$$
\frac{c}{b} = \frac{BQ}{QC} = \frac{BS}{SC}.
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{align*}
\frac{BC}{QC} &= \frac{QC}{QC} + \frac{BQ}{QC} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{QC} &= 1 + \frac{c}{b} \\
\Rightarrow \quad QC &= \frac{ab}{b+c}
\end{align*}
$$

and

$$
\begin{align*}
\frac{BC}{SC} &= \frac{BS}{SC} - \frac{SC}{SC} && (C \text{ is between } B \text{ and } S) \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{SC} &= \frac{c}{b} - 1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad SC &= \frac{ab}{c-b}.
\end{align*}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{align*}
QS &= QC + SC \quad (C \text{ is between } B \text{ and } S) \\
   &= \frac{ab}{b+c} + \frac{ab}{c-b} \\
   &= \frac{2abc}{c^2-b^2}.
\end{align*}
$$

We also have

$$
\begin{align*}
c^2 &= AR^2 + BR^2 && (\text{Pythagoras}) \\
    &= AR^2 + (PR + BP)^2 \\
    &= AR^2 + PR^2 + BP^2 + 2BP \cdot PR \\
    &= AP^2 + BP^2 + a \cdot PR && (\text{Pythagoras in } \triangle APR) \\
    &= \frac{1}{2}(b^2 + c^2) + a \cdot PR && (\text{Apollonius Theorem in } \triangle ABC) \\
\Rightarrow PR &= \frac{c^2 - b^2}{2a}.
\end{align*}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{align*}
PR \cdot QS &= \frac{c^2 - b^2}{2a} \cdot \frac{2abc}{c^2 - b^2} \\
&= bc \\
&= AB \cdot AC
\end{align*}
$$

as required.

We may now compute points P, Q, R, S.

Since P is the midpoint of BC it is given by

$$
P = \frac{b^2 + c^2}{2}.
$$

Point Q is the intersection of lines AQ and BC. Solving the system

$$
\begin{aligned} z + a^2bc\bar{z} &= a^2 + bc \\ z + b^2c^2\bar{z} &= b^2 + c^2 \end{aligned}
$$

yields

$$
Q = \frac{a^2b^2 + a^2c^2 - a^2bc - b^2c^2}{a^2 - bc}.
$$

Replacing $b$ with $-b$ in the expression for $Q$, yields the expression for $S$

$$
S = \frac{a^2b^2 + a^2c^2 + a^2bc - b^2c^2}{a^2 + bc}.
$$

For point R, it is well known that the reflection of the orthocentre of a triangle in any of its three sides lies on the circumcircle of the triangle. Thus if H is the orthocentre and H' is the intersection of AH with the circumcircle, we have that R is the midpoint of HH'. It is well known that $\vec{OH} = 3 \vec{OG}$, where G is the centroid and O is the circumcentre of triangle ABC. Since $G = \frac{a^2+b^2+c^2}{3}$, we have $H = a^2+b^2+c^2$. Furthermore if $H' = z$, then since A, H, H' are collinear, we must have $H' - A = r(H - A)$ for some real number $r$. Thus $z - a^2 = r(b^2 + c^2)$. Taking the complex conjugate and using $\bar{z} = \frac{1}{z}$, $\bar{a} = \frac{1}{a}$, $\bar{b} = \frac{1}{b}$, $\bar{c} = \frac{1}{a}$, we find $\frac{1}{z} - \frac{1}{a^2} = \frac{r(b^2+c^2)}{b^2c^2} = \frac{z-a^2}{b^2c^2}$. A little tidying up allows us to cancel a factor of $z - a^2$, since $z \neq a^2$, and thus find $z = -\frac{b^2c^2}{a^2}$. Since R is the midpoint of H and H' we deduce

$$
R = \frac{1}{2} \left( a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - \frac{b^2c^2}{a^2} \right).
$$

We can now calculate the values of PR and QS.

$$
\begin{aligned} PR &= \left| \frac{1}{2} \left( a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - \frac{b^2c^2}{a^2} \right) - \frac{1}{2} (b^2 + c^2) \right| \\ &= \frac{|a^4 - b^2c^2|}{2|a^2|} \end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned} QS &= \left| \frac{a^2bc+b^2c^2-a^2b^2-a^2c^2}{bc-a^2} - \frac{a^2bc-b^2c^2+a^2b^2+a^2c^2}{bc+a^2} \right| \\ &= \frac{2|bc(a^2-b^2)(a^2-c^2)|}{|a^4-b^2c^2|} \end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{align*}
PR \cdot QS &= \frac{|a^4 - b^2c^2|}{2|a^2|} \cdot \frac{2|bc(a^2 - b^2)(a^2 - c^2)|}{|a^4 - b^2c^2|} \\
&= \frac{|bc|}{|a^2|} \cdot |a^2 - b^2| \cdot |a^2 - c^2| \\
&= |a^2 - b^2| \cdot |a^2 - c^2| \quad (\text{since } |a| = |b| = |c| = 1) \\
&= AB \cdot AC.

This solution uses complex numbers. We shall need to know the equation of a line which passes through two complex numbers $u$ and $v$. All points on this line are given by $ru + (1-r)v$ as $r$ ranges over the real numbers. Thus the equation of the line is $z = ru + (1-r)v = v + r(u-v)$. Thus $r = \frac{z-v}{u-v}$. Taking the complex conjugate of both sides yields $r = \frac{\bar{z}-\bar{v}}{\bar{u}-\bar{v}}$. Equating the two expressions for $r$ yields

$$
\frac{z - v}{u - v} = \frac{\bar{z} - \bar{v}}{\bar{u} - \bar{v}}.
$$

This rearranges as

$$
z(\bar{u} - \bar{v}) - \bar{z}(u - v) = \bar{u}v - u\bar{v}.
$$

However, for the problem at hand we will only ever need to consider when $u, v$ lie on the unit circle. Thus $u\bar{u} = v\bar{v} = 1$ so that $\bar{u} = \frac{1}{u}$ and $\bar{v} = \frac{1}{v}$. Thus our equation simplifies to

$$
z + \bar{z}uv = u + v.
$$

One final preparatory point. If $u, v$ are on the unit circle, then the two quantities $\pm\sqrt{uv}$ represent the two midpoints of the arcs (the major arc and the minor arc) joining $u$ to $v$ in some order.

We now proceed to the given problem.

Without loss of generality we may assume that the circumcircle of triangle $ABC$ is the unit circle in the complex plane. Let $a^2, b^2, c^2$ be the complex numbers representing points $A, B, C$, respectively.

Note that the internal and external angle bisectors at $A$ are the lines $AQ$ and $AS$, respectively. These intersect the unit circle at the midpoints of the two arcs which join $B$ and $C$. These two points are thus $bc$ and $-bc$ in some order. By choosing the value of $b$ appropriately (there are two choices for $b$ such that $B = b^2$) we may assume that $AQ$ intersects the circumcircle at $bc$ and $AS$ intersects the circumcircle at $-bc$. Thus we have the equations given below for lines $AQ$ and $AS$. We also have the equation for line $BC$.

$$

$$

$$
AS: z - a^2bc\bar{z} = a^2 - bc
$$

$$
BC: z + b^2c^2\bar{z} = b^2 + c^2.

Of all the primes less than 20, we may check directly that 2, 3, 5, 7 and 13 are good. But the primes 11, 17 and 19 are bad, since $11 \equiv 4 \pmod 7$, $17 \equiv 4 \pmod{13}$ and $19 \equiv 4 \pmod 5$.

Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that there is a prime $p > 20$ such that $p$ is good. Consider $p-4$. If $p-4$ has a prime factor $q$ which is greater than 4, then we would have $p \equiv 4 \pmod q$, a contradiction. Hence all prime factors of $p-4$ must be less than 4. Since $p-4$ is odd we must have $p-4 = 3^a$ for some positive integer $a$.

Consider $p-8$. If $p-8$ has a prime factor $q$ which is greater than 8, then we would have $p \equiv 8 \pmod q$, a contradiction. Thus all prime factors of $p-8$ must be less than 8. Note that $p-8$ is odd, so that 2 is not a factor of $p-8$. From earlier $p-4 = 3^a$. So, $p-8 = 3^a-4$. Hence 3 is not a factor of $p-8$. Thus $p-8 = 5^{b_1} \cdot 7^{b_2}$, for non-negative integers $b_1, b_2$.

Consider $p-9$. By a similar argument as before we see that $p-9$ can have no prime factors greater than 9. Furthermore, $p-9 = 3^a-5$. Thus $p-9$ is not divisible by 3 or 5. Hence $p-9 = 2^{c_1} \cdot 7^{c_2}$.

Finally, consider $p-12$. By a similar argument $p-12$ has no prime factors greater than 12. Since $p-12 = 3^a-8$ we see that $p-12$ is not divisible by 2 or 3. Thus $p-12 = 5^{d_1} \cdot 7^{d_2} \cdot 11^{d_3}$ for non-negative integers $d_1, d_2, d_3$.

To summarise so far, if $p > 20$ is a good prime then

$$
\begin{aligned}
p-4 &= 3^a \\
p-8 &= 5^{b_1} \cdot 7^{b_2} \\
p-9 &= 2^{c_1} \cdot 7^{c_2} \\
p-12 &= 5^{d_1} \cdot 7^{d_2} \cdot 11^{d_3}.
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose that $c_2 = 0$, thus $p-9 = 3^a-5 = 2^{c_1}$. Since $p > 20$ we have $c_1 > 2$. Hence $3^a \equiv 5 \pmod 8$. However the powers of 3 modulo 8 cycle as 1, 3, 1, 3, ..., a contradiction. Hence $c_2 \ge 1$. Thus $p-9$ is divisible by 7. Hence neither of $p-8$ or $p-12$ are divisible by 7. Thus $b_2 = d_2 = 0$. Furthermore, since $p-8 = 5^{b_1}$, it necessarily follows that $b_1 > 0$ and so $p-8$ is divisible by 5. But then $p-12$ cannot be divisible by 5. Thus $d_1 = 0$. Hence

$$
p-12 = 3^a - 8 = 11^{d_3}
$$

with $d_3 > 0$. Hence $3^a \equiv 8 \pmod{11}$. However, powers of 3 modulo 11 cycle as 1, 3, 9, 5, 4, 1, 3, 9, 5, 4, ..., a contradiction. This contradiction establishes that there are no more good primes.

Let $O$ be the centre of circles $K$ and $L$. Let $R$ be the second intersection point of $PC$ with circle $K$. Since $\angle APR = 90^\circ$ it follows that $AR$ is a diameter of circle $K$. Thus $O$ is the midpoint of $AR$.

Furthermore triangles $OBP$ and $OCR$ are congruent (SAS). This follows from $\angle BOP = \angle OPR - \angle OBP = \angle ORP - \angle OCR = \angle COR$, $OB = OC$ and $OP = OR$. Hence $PB = RC$ and so $PC = BR$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2010_p116_data_e875db2b33.png)

From Pythagoras Theorem we have

\[
PA^2 + PB^2 = AB^2.
\]

Thus

\[
PA^2 + PB^2 + PC^2 = AB^2 + BR^2.
\]

Since $O$ is the midpoint of $AR$ we may apply Apollonius Theorem to triangle $ABR$ to get

\[
\begin{aligned}
AB^2 + BR^2 &= 2OB^2 + 2(\frac{1}{2}AR)^2 \\
&= 2s^2 + 2r^2.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
PA^2 + PB^2 + PC^2 = 2r^2 + 2s^2.
\]

We have the following factorizations of numbers appearing in the problem:

$$
\begin{align*}
845 &= 5 \cdot 13^2 \\
325 &= 5^2 \cdot 13 \\
847 &= 7 \cdot 11^2 \\
539 &= 7^2 \cdot 11 \\
245 &= 5 \cdot 7^2 \\
175 &= 5^2 \cdot 7 \\
1889 &= 11 \cdot 13^2 \\
1573 &= 11^2 \cdot 13.
\end{align*}
$$

Let $a = \sqrt[3]{5}$, $b = \sqrt[3]{7}$, $c = \sqrt[3]{11}$ and $d = \sqrt[3]{13}$. Note that

$$
\frac{a^3 + d^3}{3} = 6
$$

$$
\frac{b^3+c^3}{3} = 6
$$

$$
\frac{a^3+b^3}{3} = 4
$$

$$
\frac{c^3+d^3}{3} = 8.
$$

Using this we may compute

$$
\begin{align*}
\sqrt[3]{6 + \sqrt[3]{845} + \sqrt[3]{325}} &= \sqrt[3]{\frac{a^3+d^3}{3} + ad^2 + a^2d} \\
&= \frac{\sqrt[3]{a^3+d^3+3ad^2+3a^2d}}{\sqrt[3]{3}} \\
&= \frac{a+d}{\sqrt[3]{3}}
\end{align*}
$$

where we have used the identity $(a+d)^3 = a^3 + 3a^2d + 3ad^2 + d^3$.

Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{align*}
\sqrt[3]{6 + \sqrt[3]{847} + \sqrt[3]{539}} &= \frac{b+c}{\sqrt[3]{3}} \\
\sqrt[3]{4 + \sqrt[3]{245} + \sqrt[3]{175}} &= \frac{a+b}{\sqrt[3]{3}} \\
\sqrt[3]{8 + \sqrt[3]{1889} + \sqrt[3]{1573}} &= \frac{c+d}{\sqrt[3]{3}}
\end{align*}
$$

Thus the LHS and RHS of the expression given in the problem are both
equal to $\frac{a+b+c+d}{\sqrt[3]{3}}$. Hence LHS = RHS, as required.

Note that we have shown more, namely, the common value is equal to

$$
\frac{\sqrt[3]{5} + \sqrt[3]{7} + \sqrt[3]{11} + \sqrt[3]{13}}{\sqrt[3]{3}}.
$$

Let $p_1, p_2, p_3, p_4$ be the primes 2, 3, 5, 67. Let $e_i = \frac{2010}{p_i}$ for $i = 1, 2, 3, 4$. We shall prove that at least one of the $e_i$ satisfies the conditions.

Note that each $e_i$ satisfies (i) and (ii). Assume for the sake of contradiction that none of the $e_i$ satisfy (iii). Thus for each $i \in \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ there exists a pair $x, y$ of distinct elements of $\{a, b, c, d\}$ such that $x \equiv y \pmod{e_i}$.

Define a graph $G$ with four vertices labeled $a, b, c, d$ as follows. Two vertices $x, y$ are joined by an edge with label $e_i$ if $x \equiv y \pmod{e_i}$. Note that $G$ has at least four edges, one for each $e_i$. It is well known, and easy to prove, that any graph on $n$ vertices which has at least $n$ edges, must contain a cycle. In our case $n = 4$ and so $G$ must contain a cycle.

The definition of $G$ precludes it from having a 1-cycle.

If $G$ contained a 2-cycle, there would exist two distinct members $x, y$ of $\{a, b, c, d\}$ such that $x \equiv y \pmod{e_i}$ and $y \equiv x \pmod{e_j}$ for $i \neq j$. Since $\text{lcm}(e_i, e_j) = 2010$ for $i \neq j$ it follows that $x \equiv y \pmod{2010}$, a contradiction.

If $G$ contained a 3-cycle, there would exist three distinct members $x, y, z$ of $\{a, b, c, d\}$ such that

$$
x \equiv y \pmod{e_i}
$$

$$
y \equiv z \pmod{e_j}
$$

$$
z \equiv x \pmod{e_k}
$$

for some $i, j, k$ distinct members of $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$. Since $p_k|e_i$ and $p_k|e_j$, the first two congruences imply that $x \equiv z \pmod{p_k}$. This along with the third congruence implies that $x \equiv z \pmod{2010}$ since $\text{lcm}(p_k, e_k) = 2010$. This is a contradiction.

If $G$ contained a 4-cycle, there would exist a permutation $(x, y, z, w)$ of $(a, b, c, d)$ such that

$$
x \equiv y \pmod{e_i}
$$

$$
y \equiv z \pmod{e_j}
$$

$$
z \equiv w \pmod{e_k}
$$

$$
w \equiv z \pmod{e_\ell}
$$

where $(i, j, k, \ell)$ is a permutation of $(1, 2, 3, 4)$. Since $p_k, p_\ell|e_i, e_j$, the first two congruences imply that $x \equiv z \pmod{p_k p_\ell}$. Since $p_i, p_j|e_k, e_\ell$, the last two congruences imply that $x \equiv z \pmod{p_i p_j}$. Since $\text{lcm}(p_k p_\ell, p_i p_j) = 2010$, we conclude that $x \equiv z \pmod{2010}$, a contradiction.

Thus in all cases $G$ contains no cycle. This contradicts our earlier observation about $G$. Thus one of the $e_i$ is a suitable candidate for $e$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2010_p120_data_9e8e5d9e7d.png)

We claim that the points $B, M, S, D, C$ occur in that order on the segment $BC$. We know $BM = \frac{a}{2}$. Also $S$ is the point of contact of the incircle with $BC$, thus $BS = s - b = \frac{a+c-b}{2}$ from the standard incircle substitution. Finally, $BD = c \cdot \cos \angle B = c \cdot \frac{a^2+c^2-b^2}{2ac} = \frac{a^2+c^2-b^2}{2a}$ from the cosine rule. We have

$$
\begin{array}{l@{\qquad}l@{\qquad}l}
BM < BS < BD & & \\
\Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{a}{2} < \frac{a+c-b}{2} < \frac{a^2+c^2-b^2}{2a} & & \\
\Leftrightarrow \quad 0 < c-b < \frac{c^2-b^2}{a} & & \\
\Leftrightarrow \quad 0 < a(c-b) < (c-b)(c+b), & &
\end{array}
$$

which is true since $b < c$ and $a < b + c$ from the triangle inequality.

$$
\begin{array}{l@{\qquad}l@{\qquad}l}

\Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{a^2+c^2-b^2}{2c} < \frac{a+c-b}{2} < \frac{c}{2} & & \\

As in the first alternative we model the situation with a graph $G$ on $n$ vertices representing the $n$ people and each acquaintanceship is represented by an edge. As in the first alternative, we define a \textit{good} pair to be two persons who are not acquainted but who share a common acquaintance with someone else.

Let the total number of edges in the graph be $E$. Thus there are at most $\binom{n}{2} - E$ good pairs. If $E \ge n - 1$, then the number of good pairs is at most $\binom{n}{2} - (n-1) = \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2}$.

Suppose instead that $E \le n - 2$. A well known theorem states that a connected graph on $n$ vertices has at least $n-1$ edges. Since we have at most $n-2$ edges, this means that our graph is disconnected and can be partitioned into two smaller subgraphs, $G_1$ and $G_2$, say, such that there are no edges going between $G_1$ and $G_2$. Consider a person $X$, say, in $G_1$ and a person, $Y$ say, in $G_2$. Since $G_1$ and $G_2$ are disconnected, this means that $X$ and $Y$ cannot have a common acquaintance. Thus the pair $X,Y$ is not good. If $G_1$ has $m$ vertices then $G_2$ has $n-m$ vertices then this means we have at least $m(n-m)$ pairs which are not good. Note that $f(m) = m(n-m)$ is a negative quadratic in $m$ and thus achieves its minimum at the extremal points permitted for $m$, namely at $m = 1$ or $m = n-1$. Since $f(1) = f(n-1) = n-1$ we conclude that there are at least $n-1$ pairs which are not good. Thus the number of good pairs is once again less than or equal to $\binom{n}{2} - (n-1) = \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} = \binom{n-1}{2}$.

The equality case is constructed in the same way as the first alternative.

We represent the situation with a graph as in the first and second alternatives, defining a good pair in the same way.

Let the total number of edges in the graph be $E$. If $X$ and $Y$ are a good pair, this means that there exists a point $Z$ such that $XZ$ and $YZ$ are edges. Thus to each good pair, we can associate at least one pair of edges. Furthermore different good pairs lead to different pairs of associated edges. Thus the number of good pairs is less than or equal to the number of pairs of edges. Thus the number of good pairs is at most $\binom{E}{2}$.

Also since there are $E$ edges, this means that there are $\binom{n}{2} - E$ non-edges. Thus the number of good pairs is bounded above by $\binom{n}{2} - E$.

Thus the number of good pairs is at most $\min\{\binom{E}{2}, \binom{n}{2} - E\}$. Consider the graphs of the two functions $f(E) = \frac{E(E-1)}{2}$ and $g(E) = \frac{n(n-1)}{2} - E$ for fixed $n$. Note that $f(0) = f(1)$ and that $f(E)$ is an increasing function for $E \ge 1$. Also note that $g(E)$ is a decreasing function of $E$. Thus the maximum value of $\min\{f(E), g(E)\}$ occurs when $f(E) = g(E)$. Solving the equation $\frac{E(E-1)}{2} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2} - E$ yields $E = n-1$ or $E = -n$. Only the first solution is valid. Thus there are at most $f(E) = f(n-1) = \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2}$ good pairs.

The equality case is constructed the same way as in the first alternative.

Let us call a pair of people \textit{good} if they are not acquainted, but share a common acquaintance with someone else. Let there be $k$ such good pairs.

Let us model the situation by a graph $G$ with $n$ vertices representing the $n$ people. Let there be an edge between vertices $A$ and $B$ if persons $A$ and $B$ are acquainted. Since there are $k$ good pairs, this graph has at most $\binom{n}{2} - k$ edges.

Let $X$ and $Y$ be a good pair. Thus there is at least one vertex $Z$ such that $XZ$ and $YZ$ are both edges. Hence to each good pair we can associate at least two edges. Furthermore any edge, say $PQ$, which arises from a good pair can only arise from at most $n - 2$ good pairs. This is because for each other point $R$ in the graph, if $R$ is joined to exactly one of $P$ or $Q$, then we add one to the count as it pertains to the edge $PQ$ arising from a good pair. In all other cases we add zero to the count as it pertains to the edge $PQ$ arising from a good pair.

Thus each edge arising from a good pair is counted at most $n - 2$ times. This means that the number of edges it at least $\frac{2k}{n-2}$. Since the graph has at most $\binom{n}{2} - k$ edges, we deduce that $\frac{2k}{n-2} \le \binom{n}{2} - k$. This simplifies to $k \le \frac{n^2-3n+2}{2} = \binom{n-1}{2}$.

Finally we show that $k = \binom{n-1}{2}$ is attainable. Consider the scenario where one person, say $P$, knows all the other people, but none of the other people know each other. Then every pair of the $n-1$ persons not containing $P$ is a good pair. Thus there are exactly $k = \binom{n-1}{2}$ good pairs in this scenario.

Extend \textit{CH} and \textit{BH} to intersect the circumcircle of triangle \textit{ABC} at \textit{D} and \textit{E}, respectively. We establish some easy facts by simple angle chasing.

From cyclic quadrilateral \textit{AMHC} and also using the facts that \textit{CH} \perp \textit{AB} and \textit{BH} \perp \textit{AC}, we have $\angle BMH = \angle ACH = 90^\circ - \angle BAC = \angle MBH$. Thus \textit{CD} is a line of symmetry in triangle \textit{BMH}.

Also $\angle BDC = \angle BAC = 90^\circ - \angle MBH = \angle BHD$. Thus \textit{AB} is a line of symmetry for triangle \textit{DBH}. Since quadrilateral \textit{HBDM} has two perpendicular lines of symmetry, this means that it is a rhombus. Similarly \textit{HCEN} is also a rhombus. Furthermore since $\angle BDH = \angle CEH$ we have that the rhombi are similar. This will be in important in the sequel.

Let $\ell_B$ and $\ell_C$ be the perpendicular bisectors of $BD$ and $CE$, respectively. Since $BD$ and $CE$ are chords of the circumcircle of triangle $ABC$, it follows that $O$ is the intersection of $\ell_B$ and $\ell_C$. Let $m_B$ and $m_C$ be the perpendicular bisectors of $MH$ and $NH$, respectively. Thus $m_B$ and $m_C$ intersect at the circumcentre of triangle $MHN$, which we shall denote by $Q$.

Consider the dilation about \textit{H} which takes $\ell_B$ to $m_B$. Since the two rhombi \textit{HBDM} and \textit{HCEN} are similar the dilation also takes $\ell_C$ to $m_C$. Hence the dilation takes $\ell_B \cap \ell_C$ to $m_B \cap m_C$ and hence takes \textit{O} to \textit{Q}. Since \textit{H} is the centre of dilation, we conclude that \textit{H}, \textit{Q} and \textit{O} are collinear.

Let us now substitute, in turn, the triples $(rx, ry, 1)$ and $(r^2x, y, 1)$, into the original functional equation and compare the results.

\[
\begin{aligned}
f(f(rx)+f(ry)+f(1)) &= f(f(rx)-f(ry))+f(2r^2xy+f(1))+2f(r(x-y)) \\
f(f(r^2x)+f(y)+f(1)) &= f(f(r^2x)-f(y))+f(2r^2xy+f(1))+2f(r^2x-y).
\end{aligned}
\]

Remember from (5) that $f(x) = f(rx) = f(r^2x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Thus

\[

Put $x = 2$, $y = -\frac{1}{2}$ to find $b = 0 \lfloor 0 \rfloor = 0$. Put $x = 1$, $y = -1$ to find $a = b \lfloor a \rfloor = 0$. Thus $f$ is the zero function which has been disallowed by the beginning of case 2b. So this case does not occur.

**Case 2bii.** $\lfloor t \rfloor = 1$. Thus $f(x) = t$ for all $x \ge 2$. We also have $f(x) = 0$ for all $0 \le x < 1$. Let $1 \le x < 2$ and $y > 2$. Then $\lfloor x \rfloor y = y > 2$. Thus $t = f(\lfloor x \rfloor y) = f(x) \lfloor f(y) \rfloor = f(\lfloor x \rfloor) \lfloor t \rfloor = f(1) \cdot 1$. Thus $t = f(1)$. Hence we have $f(x) = t$ for all $x \ge 1$. Set $x = -1$ and $y \ge 1$. Then $f(-y) = f(-1) \lfloor f(y) \rfloor = f(-1) \lfloor t \rfloor = f(-1)$. Thus $f(x) = v$ for all $x \le -1$ for some constant $v$. Also $f(x) = f(-1)$ whenever $-1 \le x < 0$. Thus $f$ is piecewise linear in the following fashion:

$$
f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x \in [0, 1) \\ t & x \ge 1 \\ v & x < 0 \end{cases}
$$

where $t, v$ are real constants with $\lfloor t \rfloor = 1$.

Put $x = 2$, $y = \frac{1}{2}$ to find $t = t \lfloor 0 \rfloor = 0$. This contradicts $\lfloor t \rfloor = 1$. So this
case does not occur either.

**Comment.** Some of the above solutions have a number of elements in common. In fact it is possible to distil the essential elements of some of these solutions into a much shorter and direct solution. We leave this as an instructive exercise for the reader. This is of course much easier in reflective hindsight without the pressures of writing the IMO exam!

The problem is reduced to the task of proving the second relation in the lemma of the first alternative. We refer to the diagram used in the lemma of the previous solution in the following proof.

Use the standard notation of $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, $2\alpha = \angle BAC$, $2\beta = \angle ABC$, $2\gamma = \angle ACB$ and let R be the circumradius of triangle ABC. Note that $\alpha+\beta+\gamma = 90^\circ$. Let BI meet AC at S. Apply Menelaus Theorem to triangle AMC with transversal BS. After rearranging we obtain

$$ 
\begin{align*} 
\frac{AI}{IM} &= \frac{BC}{MB} \cdot \frac{AS}{CS} && \text{(Menelaus' Theorem)} \\ 
&= \frac{MB + MC}{MB} \cdot \frac{c}{a} && \text{(angle bisector theorem)} \\ 
&= \left(1 + \frac{MC}{MB}\right) \cdot \frac{c}{a} \\ 
&= \left(1 + \frac{b}{c}\right) \cdot \frac{c}{a} && \text{(angle bisector theorem)} \\ 
&= \frac{b+c}{a} \\ 
&= \frac{2R \sin 2\beta + 2R \sin 2\gamma}{2R \sin 2\alpha} && \text{(extended sine rule)} \\ 
&= \frac{2 \sin(\beta + \gamma) \cos(\beta - \gamma)}{2 \sin \alpha \cos \alpha} && \text{(sum to product rule)} \\ 
&= \frac{\cos(\gamma - \beta)}{\sin \alpha} && \text{($\alpha + \beta + \gamma = 90^\circ$)} 
\end{align*} 
$$

For the ratio $AD/ID$, it is proven that $DI = DB$ as in the first alternative. Also a simple angle chase yields $\angle ABD = 2\beta + \angle DBC = 2\beta + \angle DAC = \alpha + 2\beta$. \frac{AD}{ID} = \frac{\cos(\gamma - \beta)}{\sin \alpha} = \frac{AI}{IM},

From here on we use the same standard angle notation ($\angle BAC = 2\alpha$ etc.) as used in the second alternative. The remainder of the proof will be some angle chasing followed by a trigonometric calculation.

For the ratio $\frac{AF}{AD'}$, we will need to know the following angles:

\[
\begin{align*}
\angle ABF &= 2\beta \\
\angle AEB &= \angle ACB = 2\gamma \\
\angle ABD' &= 90^\circ + \beta \\
\angle AD'B &= 90^\circ - \alpha - \beta = \gamma.
\end{align*}
\]

We also let $\angle AFB = \theta$. Thus from the sine rule in triangles \textit{ABF} and \textit{ABD'} we find

\[
\frac{AF}{AB} = \frac{\sin 2\beta}{\sin \theta} \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{AB}{AD'} = \frac{\sin \gamma}{\sin(90^\circ + \beta)}.
\]

Multiplying these fractions together and using $\sin(90^\circ + \beta) = \cos \beta$ yields

\[
\frac{AF}{AD'} = \frac{\sin 2\beta \sin \gamma}{\sin \theta \cos \beta} = \frac{2 \sin \beta \sin \gamma}{\sin \theta}.
\]

For the ratio $\frac{AI}{AE}$ we will need to know the following angles:

\[
\begin{align*}
\angle AEB &= 2\gamma \\
\angle ABE &= \angle AFC = 180^\circ - \theta \quad (\triangle ABE \sim \triangle AFC) \\
\angle ABI &= \beta \\
\angle AIB &= 180^\circ - \alpha - \beta = 90^\circ + \gamma.
\end{align*}
\]

From the sine rule in triangles \textit{AIB} and \textit{AEB} we find

\[
\frac{AI}{AB} = \frac{\sin \beta}{\sin(90^\circ + \gamma)} \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{AB}{AE} = \frac{\sin 2\gamma}{\sin(180^\circ - \theta)}.
\]

Multiplying these fractions together yields

\[
\frac{AI}{AE} = \frac{\sin \beta \sin 2\gamma}{\cos \gamma \sin \theta} = \frac{2 \sin \beta \sin \gamma}{\sin \theta}.
\]

Thus $\frac{AF}{AD'} = \frac{AI}{AE}$, completing the proof.

From the Power of a Point Theorem we have $SC^2 = SA \cdot SB$. But since $SC = SP$, it follows that $SP^2 = SA \cdot SB$. Thus by the converse of the Power of a Point Theorem, it follows that $SP$ is tangent to the circle passing through points $ABP$. Thus by the Alternate Segment Theorem (AST) we have $\angle BPS = \angle BAP$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2010_p160_data_3289783a94.png)

The remainder of the problem is a simple angle chase.

\[
\begin{align*}
\angle BPC &= \angle BPS + \angle SPC \\
            &= \angle BAP + \angle SCP \\
            &= \angle BAP + \angle BCP + \angle BCS \\
            &= \angle BAP + \angle BCP + \angle BAC. \quad (\text{AST})
\end{align*}
\]

Furthermore from the exterior angle in quadrilateral $ABPC$ we have

\[
\angle BPC = \angle ABP + \angle ACP + \angle BAC.
\]

Thus equating the two expressions for $\angle BPC$ we have

\[
\angle ABP + \angle ACP = \angle BAP + \angle BCP. \quad (*)
\]

However, $\angle ABP = \angle ABL$ and $\angle ACP = \angle ACM = \angle ABM$. It follows that LHS(*) = $\angle ABL + \angle ABM = \angle MBL$. Similarly, $\angle BAP = \angle BAK$ and $\angle BCP = \angle BCM = \angle BAM$. Thus RHS(*) = $\angle BAK + \angle BAM = \angle MAK$.

Hence $\angle MAK = \angle MBL$. Since arcs $MK$ and $ML$ subtend angles of equal size, we conclude that $MK = ML$, as required.

Let $t = \frac{1}{3}(2010^{2010^{2010}} - 2^m - 2r)$. Note that $r$ was specially chosen so that $t$ is an integer. Indeed, $t$ is an integer precisely when $3|2^{m-1}+r$, that is when $3|(-1)^{m-1}+r$. But our earlier specification of $r$ depending on the parity of $m$ has ensured this. Note also that $t < \frac{1}{3}2010^{2010^{2010}} < 2^m$. Perform $t$ type 1 operations on box $B_5$ and then $2^{2^{19}} - m - r$ type 2 operations (noting that this is an odd number) on box $B_4$ to arrive at

\[
(0, 0, 0, 2^{2^{19}} - m - r, 2^m + 2r, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 2^{2^{19}} - m - r, 2^m + 2r - t, 2t) \\ \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 0, 2t, 2^m + 2r - t).
\]

Finally perform $2t$ type 1 operations on box $B_5$ to arrive at

\[
(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2^m + 2r + 3t).
\]

The last term is equal to $2^m+2r+3\cdot\frac{1}{3}(2010^{2010^{2010}} - 2^m - 2r) = 2010^{2010^{2010}}$, as required.

There are still two final details to explain in order to complete the proof.

The first is that when we arrived at the position at (*) we still needed to justify why $2^{2^{19}} - m - r$ is non-negative. Here is the proof. Since we stipulated that $2^m < 2010^{2010^{2010}}$ and $r \le 2$, we have

\[
\begin{aligned} 2^{m+r} &< 2010^{2010^{2010}} \cdot 4 \\ &< 2010^{2010^{2010}} + 1 \\ &< 2010^{2011^{2010}} \\ &< 2048^{2048^{2048}} \\ &= 2^{11 \cdot 2^{11 \cdot 2^{11}}} \\ &< 2^{11 \cdot 2^{2^{15}}} \quad (11 < 2^4) \\ &< 2^{2^{4+2^{15}}} \\ &< 2^{2^{2^{19}}}. \end{aligned}
\]

Thus $m+r < 2^{2^{19}}$, as required.

The second is that we performed $t = \frac{1}{3}(2010^{2010^{2010}} - 2^m - 2r)$ moves at some stage. We need to justify why $t$ is non-negative. Note that $2^{2010^{2010}}|2010^{2010^{2010}}$, thus $m > 2010^{2010}$. Furthermore, $2^m < 2010^{2010^{2010}}$. Thus $2010^{2010^{2010}} - 2^m$ is a positive integer which is divisible by $2^{2010^{2010}}$. Thus $2^{2010^{2010}} \le 2010^{2010^{2010}} - 2^m$. Thus $2^m + 2r < 2010^{2010^{2010}}$.

It is possible to end up with the first 5 boxes empty while the sixth contains exactly $2010^{2010^{2010}}$ coins!

**Lemma.** Suppose we have three boxes in a row which contain $a, 0, 0$ coins respectively. Then we may convert $(a, 0, 0)$ to $(0, 2^a, 0)$ using the given operations.

**Proof.** We show how to convert $(a - i, 2^i, 0)$ to $(a - i - 1, 2^{i+1}, 0)$ for $0 < i < a$. We do this by performing $2^i$ type 1 moves on the box with $2^i$ coins, then follow this by a type 2 move on the box containing $a - i$ coins. The operations may be summed up as $(a - i, 2^i, 0) \rightarrow (a - i, 0, 2^{i+1}) \rightarrow (a - i - 1, 2^{i+1}, 0)$. Thus we may inductively convert the arrangement of boxes as follows

\[
(a, 0, 0) \rightarrow (a - 1, 2, 0) \rightarrow (a - 2, 2^2, 0) \rightarrow (a - 3, 2^3, 0) \rightarrow \dots \rightarrow (0, 2^a, 0).
\]

This concludes the proof of the lemma.

From the initial starting point we may perform type 1 operations as follows

\[
(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) \rightarrow (0, 3, 1, 1, 1, 1) \ (0, 2, 3, 1, 1, 1).
\]

Next perform type 1 operations on $B_3$ until it contains one coin and then do the same to $B_4$. Then perform type 1 operations on $B_5$ until it is empty.

\[
(0, 2, 3, 1, 1, 1) \rightarrow (0, 2, 1, 5, 1, 1) \rightarrow (0, 2, 1, 1, 9, 1) \rightarrow (0, 2, 1, 1, 0, 19).
\]

Next perform a single type 2 move on each of $B_4, B_3$ and $B_2$ in succession to arrive at

\[
(0, 2, 1, 1, 0, 19) \rightarrow (0, 2, 1, 0, 19, 0) \rightarrow (0, 2, 0, 19, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 1, 19, 0, 0, 0).
\]

From the lemma we may convert this to $(0, 1, 0, 2^{19}, 0, 0)$. Then apply a type 1 operation and then the lemma again to arrive at

\[
(0, 1, 0, 2^{19}, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 2^{19}, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 2^{29}, 0, 0).
\]

Let $2^m$ be the largest power of 2 which is less than $2010^{2010^{2010}}$. If we perform the sequence of moves described in the lemma until box $B_5$ contains $2^m$ coins, the position becomes $(0, 0, 0, 2^{2^{19}} - m, 2^m, 0)$. If $m$ is even set $r = 1$. If $m$ is odd set $r = 2$. Perform $r$ type 1 moves on box $B_4$ to arrive at

\[
(0, 0, 0, 2^{2^{19}} - m - r, 2^m + 2r, 0). \quad (*)
\]

**Second Alternative**

Based on one of the official solutions.

**Lemma 1.** $(a, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 2^a, 0)$ for any positive integer $a$.

This is proven as in the first alternative.

**Lemma 2.** $(a, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 2 * a, 0, 0)$ for any positive integer $a$, where the notation $2 * a$ is defined by $2 * 1 = 2$ and $2 * (n + 1) = 2^{2*n}$ for $n = 1, 2, \dots$. Informally, $2 * a$ represents $2^{2^{\cdot \cdot 2}}$ where there are $a$ 2s in the power tower.

**Proof.** We show how to convert $(a - i, 2 * i, 0, 0)$ to $(a - i - 1, 2 * (i + 1), 0, 0)$ for $0 < i < a$. We do this by via

$$
\begin{align*}
(a - i, 2 * i, 0, 0) &\rightarrow (a - i, 0, 2^{2*i}, 0, 0) && \text{(using lemma 1)} \\
&= (a - i, 0, 2 * (i + 1), 0) \\
&\rightarrow (a - i - 1, 2 * (i + 1), 0, 0) && \text{(type 2 operation).}
\end{align*}
$$

Now use a type 1 operation to do $(a, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (a - 1, 2, 0, 0)$. Then inductively proceed the rest of the way via

$$
(a-1, 2*1, 0, 0) \rightarrow (a-2, 2*2, 0, 0) \rightarrow (a-3, 2*3, 0, 0) \rightarrow \dots \rightarrow (0, 2*a, 0, 0).
$$

Using these lemmas we now show how to arrive at $A = 2010^{2010^{2010}}$ coins in the sixth box. The first few moves are: $(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) \rightarrow (1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 3) \rightarrow (1, 1, 1, 0, 3, 0) \rightarrow (1, 1, 0, 3, 0, 0) \rightarrow (1, 0, 3, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0)$.

Next apply lemma 2 twice to get

$$
(0, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 2 * 3, 0, 0, 0) = (0, 0, 16, 0, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 2 * 16, 0, 0).
$$

Then waste enough type 2 operations on the fourth box to get

$$
(0, 0, 0, 2 * 16, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 2 * 16 - 1, 0, 0) \rightarrow \dots \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, A/4, 0, 0).
$$

Finally apply two more type 1 operations to arrive at $(0, 0, 0, A/4, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 0, A/2, 0, 0) \rightarrow (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, A)$, as required.

**Comment.** The real interest in this question is in the discovery that starting from $(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1)$ and using only the two given simple operations the following two facts are true:

1. The number of operations that may be performed is necessarily finite and thus the number of coins that may be achieved is bounded.

2. If the operations are chosen carefully enough, it is possible to achieve incredibly huge amounts of coins. Indeed from the initial condition it is possible to arrive at $(0, 1, 2^{14}, 0, 0, 0)$ from which it is possible to achieve more than $2 * (2 * 2^{14})$ in the last box! This is far, far more than the current estimate for the number of particles in the universe!

Choose a decomposition of $a_n$ satisfying (1), (2), (3) and (4) as in the lemma. Then we have $n = i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_k \le sk$. Thus $k \ge \frac{n}{s} \ge s\ell + 2$. Suppose that none of the numbers $i_3, i_4, \ldots, i_k$ is equal to $\ell$, then by the pigeonhole principle there is an index $j$ ($3 \le j \le s$, $j \ne \ell$) such that $j$ appears at least $\ell$ times among $i_3, i_4, \ldots, i_k$. Let us delete these $\ell$ occurrences of $j$ from $(i_1, i_2, i_3, \ldots, i_k)$ and replace them with $j$ occurrences of $\ell$ instead, obtaining a sequence $(i_1, i_2, i'_3, \ldots, i'_{k'})$. Note that this sequence also satisfies (2), (3) and (4). Furthermore, since

$$
a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + a_{i_3} + \cdots + a_{i_k} = a_n \ge a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + a_{i'_3} + \cdots + a_{i'_{k'}}
$$

from the lemma, then after canceling the coinciding terms we are left with the inequality $\ell a_j \ge j a_\ell$ and so $\frac{a_\ell}{\ell} \le \frac{a_j}{j}$. However, from the definition of $\ell$, this means that $\ell a_j = j a_\ell$. Thus we have

$$
a_n = a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + a_{i'_3} + \cdots + a_{i'_{k'}}
$$

Rearranging the indices we may assume that $i'_{k'} = \ell$. Thus we have found a representation of $a_n$ satisfying (1), (2), (3) and (4) such that $i_k = \ell$.

Finally, observe that in this representation, the indices $(i_1, \ldots, i_{k-1})$ satisfy conditions (2), (3) and (4) with $n$ replaced by $n - \ell$. Thus by the lemma we have $a_{n-\ell} + a_\ell \ge (a_{i_1} + \cdots + a_{i_{k-1}}) + a_\ell = a_n$. This implies that $a_n = a_{n-\ell} + a_\ell$ for each $n \ge s^2\ell + 2s$, as required.

Based on ideas from the presentation by Sampson Wong, year 12, James Ruse Agricultural High School, NSW. Sampson was a silver medalist with the 2010 Australian IMO team.

The two important ideas are as follows: First, any $a_n$, with $n > s$, can be decomposed into a sum $a_n = a_{j_1} + a_{j_2}$ with $j_1, j_2 < n$ and $j_1 + j_2 = n$. If say, $j_1 > s$ then we can further decompose $a_{j_1}$ in the same way, and so on until $a_n$ is written as a sum $a_n = a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + \cdots + a_{i_k}$ where $1 \le i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k \le s$.

The second idea is that suppose we have written $a_n = a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + \cdots + a_{i_k}$ as in the first idea, and the term $a_p$ appears at least $q$ times where $1 \le p \le s$ and $1 \le q \le s$. Then it might occur that $qa_p < pa_q$. In such a situation it would be better to replace $q$ terms of $a_p$ with $p$ terms of $a_q$ in the decomposition of $a_n$, if this were possible. This leads to a consideration of the maximal value of $\frac{a_i}{i}$ where $1 \le i \le s$.

The putting together of these ideas into a proof which is watertight, however, is a little tricky. We proceed as follows:

**Lemma.** The term $a_n$ satisfies

$$
a_n = \max\{a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + \cdots + a_{i_k}\} \quad (1)
$$

where $i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k$ satisfy

$$
1 \le i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k \le s \quad (2)
$$

$$
i_1 + i_2 + \cdots + i_k = n \quad (3)
$$

$$
i_1 + i_2 > s \quad (4).
$$

**Proof.** The description of the first idea shows that $a_n = a_{i_1} + a_{i_2} + \cdots + a_{i_k}$ for some $i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k$ satisfying (2), (3) and (4). The only part which is not obvious is (4). However, (4) arises at the very last point when the final term whose index is greater than $s$ is decomposed into two terms whose indices are both less than or equal to $s$.

We wish to show that $a_n$ is indeed the maximum such sum in (1). Suppose that $a_{i'_1} + a_{i'_2} + \cdots + a_{i'_k}$ is the maximum such sum in (1) such that $i'_1, i'_2, \ldots, i'_k$ satisfy (2), (3) and (4). For each $j$ let $t_j = i'_1 + i'_2 + \cdots + i'_j$. From the definition of $a_n$ we have

$$
a_n = a_{t_k} \ge a_{t_{k-1}} + a_{i'_k} \ge a_{t_{k-2}} + a_{i'_{k-1}} + a_{i'_k} \ge \dots \ge a_{i'_1} + a_{i'_2} + \cdots + a_{i'_k}.
$$

Thus since $a_n$ cannot be greater than the maximum such sum, it must be equal to the maximum such sum.

In Vortzegia, the unit of money is the finbar. The Vortzegians like to keep things simple, so they passed a law long ago stating that when you want to buy an item, the transaction must involve at most two coins including the change.

In Western Vortzegia before 2011 there were only 1-finbar and 8-finbar coins. With these coins only goods with the following values could be purchased: 1 finbar, 2 finbars (1 + 1), 7 finbars (8 - 1, pay 8 and get 1 finbar change), 8 finbars, 9 finbars (8 + 1) or 16 finbars (8 + 8).

To cover all values from 1 to 20 finbars, no two of these values can be
the same. The largest value is $2a$ so this must be 20 finbars. Hence
$a = 10$.

The only way to achieve 19 finbars is by addition, so $b = 9$.

These two coins between them cover the values 20, 19, 18, 10, 9, and 1. The next value to consider is 17 finbars, which also has to be made by addition. We cannot use an 8-finbar coin, because $9 - 8 = 1$ and we will have duplicated the 1 finbar value already obtained with $10 - 9$. So the only way to get 17 finbars is with a 7-finbar coin added to the 10-finbar coin. Hence $c = 7$.

\textbf{Alternative i}

At this point we have covered the following values: 20, 19, 18, 17, 16, 14, 10, 9, 7, 3, 2, 1.

There is only one coin left to choose, and it will have to be used to
cover all the remaining values. The next value to consider is 15 finbars.
Again, it has to be obtained by addition. It cannot be made by 10+5,
because $7 - 5 = 2$ and we already have a 2 finbar combination with
$9 - 7$. Similarly, it cannot be made with a 6-finbar coin (added to 9)
or an 8-finbar coin (added to 7) because 1 finbar will be duplicated in
both these cases. That exhausts our possible choices for making 15
finbars. Therefore, four coins are not enough.

\textbf{Alternative ii}

We have $a = 10, b = 9, c = 7$. If $d$ is odd, then 11 of the 20 values
above will be even, which is too many. So $d$ is even and must be used
to give 15. The only possible even numbers to give 15 are 8 and 6 and
again they fail the duplicate value test.

## Gradient Method

Place cartesian axes on the pentagon so that the origin is at C, the vertical axis bisects $\angle BCD = 2\theta$, and B is in the first quadrant. Let FG be the vertical line through D so that FA is horizontal. Let AB = 1.

Since $\angle ABF$ and $\angle CBG$ are complementary and $\angle BCG$ is complementary to $\theta$, $\angle FAB = \angle GBC = \theta$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2011_p77_data_0487bfe098.png)

The co-ordinates of B are $(\sin \theta, \cos \theta)$.
The co-ordinates of D are $(-\sin \theta, \cos \theta)$.
The co-ordinates of A are $(\sin \theta - \cos \theta, \cos \theta + \sin \theta)$.
Similarly, the co-ordinates of E are $(-\sin \theta + \cos \theta, \cos \theta - \sin \theta)$.
Hence the co-ordinates of M, the mid-point of AE, are
$(0, \cos \theta + \sin \theta)$.

The gradient of line BM is $\frac{\cos \theta - (\cos \theta + \sin \theta)}{\sin \theta - 0} = -1$.

The gradient of line DM is $\frac{\cos \theta - (\cos \theta + \sin \theta)}{-\sin \theta - 0} = 1$.

Hence $BM \perp DM$.

Now replace, in the given equation, $y$ by $f(y)$.

We then obtain $f(x)f(y) = f(xf(f(y))) = f(xy)$ for all $x > 0$ and all $y > 0$.

Solution 2 (Kevin McAvaney, Geelong)

Let $x = 1$. Then $yf(1) = f(1f(y)) = f(f(yf(1)))$ for all $y > 0$.

Let $t > 0$. Substituting $y = \frac{t}{f(1)}$ shows that $t = f(f(t))$ for all $t > 0$.

So in the given equation, $f(x)f(y) = f(xf(f(y))) = f(xy)$ for all $x, y > 0$.

Fact 1 – setting $x = 1$ gives $f(f(y)) = f(1)y$.

Fact 2 – setting $y = 1$ gives $f(x) = f(xf(1))$.

Replacing $y$ with $f(y)$ in the given equation, we obtain

\[
f(x)f(y) = f(xf(f(y))) = f(xyf(1)) = f(xy).
\]

(In the second equality we used Fact 1; in the final equality we used Fact 2.)

We have $f(f(xf(y))) = f(f(x)y) = f(y)x$.
Since $f(y)$ is positive and $x$ is a variable, $f(y)x$ can take any positive real value.
Hence $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x > 0$ (involution), so
$f(x)f(y) = f(xf(f(y))) = f(xy)$.

Putting $x = y = 1$ gives

\[
f(1) = f(f(1)). \tag{1}
\]

Then letting $x = \frac{1}{f(y)}$ gives

\[

\]

Finally, setting $y = \frac{1}{f(x)}$ gives

\[

Now replace, in the given equation, $y$ by $f(y)$.
We then obtain $f(x)f(y) = f(xf(f(y))) = f(xy)$ for all $x > 0$ and all $y > 0$.

Let

\[
p(x) = a_{r}x^{r} + a_{r-1}x^{r-1} + \cdots + a_{1}x + a_{0}.
\]

Since $p(m)p(n) = -(m-n)^2$, the polynomial

\[
q(x) = x^2 - \frac{p(m) - p(n)}{m-n}x + 1
\]
has $\frac{p(m)}{m-n}$ and $-\frac{p(n)}{m-n}$ as its (rational) roots.

Next, we note that the integer

\[
p(m) - p(n) = a_r(m^r - n^r) + a_{r-1}(m^{r-1} - n^{r-1}) + \dots + a_1(m - n)
\]

is divisible by $m-n$, so that $a = \frac{p(m)-p(n)}{m-n}$ is an integer.

Write $\frac{p(m)}{m-n} = \frac{b}{c}$, where $b$ and $c$ are relatively prime integers, $c > 0$.

Then $0 = q(\frac{b}{c}) = \frac{b^2}{c^2} - a\frac{b}{c} + 1$, so that $0 = b^2 - abc + c^2$, i.e. $b^2 = c(ab - c)$, implying that $c$ divides $b$, and hence $c = 1$.

Hence $\frac{p(m)}{m-n} = \frac{b}{c}$ is an integer. Similarly, $-\frac{p(n)}{m-n}$ is an integer.

Since $\frac{p(m)}{m-n}$ and $-\frac{p(n)}{m-n}$ are the roots of $q(x)$, their product equals 1, so that

\[
\frac{p(m)}{m-n} = -\frac{p(n)}{m-n} = \pm 1.
\]

Therefore $p(m) + p(n) = 0$.

\textbf{Solution 2} (Norman Do, Melbourne; Chaitanya Rao, Melbourne)

Let $p(m) = a$, $p(n) = b$ and $m-n = k$, an integer. By the fact that $m-n$ divides $p(m) - p(n)$, we know that $b = a + kd$, for some integer $d$.

We are given that $a(a + kd) = -k^2$, which implies $k^2 + adk + a^2 = 0$.

This is a quadratic equation in $k$ with discriminant $a^2(d^2 - 4)$.

For this to be a perfect square, either $a = 0$ which implies $b = 0$, or $d^2 - 4$ is a perfect square which implies $d = 2$ or $d = -2$.

Then solving the quadratic for $k$, we obtain $b = a + kd = a - 2a = -a$, so that $a + b = 0$, as required.

\textbf{Solution 3} (Ivan Guo, Sydney)

Let $q(x) = p(n+x)$ and $k = m-n \neq 0$. Then $-(m-n)^2 = -k^2$, $p(m) = q(m-n) = q(k)$ and $p(n) = q(n-n) = q(0)$.

Our given condition becomes $q(k)q(0) = -k^2$ (*), and we are trying to prove that $q(k) + q(0) = 0$.

Write $q(x) = a_m x^m + a_{m-1} x^{m-1} + \dots + a_1 x + a_0$. This may be written as $q(x) = xQ(x) + a_0$ where $Q(x) = a_m x^{m-1} + a_{m-1} x^{m-2} + \dots + a_1$. Since $q(0) = a_0$ we find $q(x) = xQ(x) + q(0)$ and

\[
q(k) = kQ(k) + q(0).
\]

Let $r$ be a prime and let $r^a \mid q(0)$ and $r^b \mid k$ ($r^k \mid N$ means that $r^k$ is the highest power of the prime $r$ which divides the integer $N$).

If $b > a$, then $b = a + t$ with $t > 0$. Thus $q(0) = cr^a$ and $k = dr^{a+t}$ where

r $\nmid$ c, d. Thus $q(k) = dr^{a+t}Q(k) + cr^a = r^a(dr^tQ(k) + c)$. Since $r \nmid c$ we see that $r \nmid dr^tQ(k) + c$. Thus $r^a \parallel q(k)$. This along with $r^a \parallel q(0)$ and $r^b \parallel k$ implies that $a = b$ upon examining (*).

This is a contradiction. Therefore $b \le a$.

Since this is true for every prime dividing $q(0)$ and $k$, this means that $k \mid q(0)$. Since $q(k) = kQ(k) + q(0)$, we also have $k \mid q(k)$. Hence $\frac{q(0)}{k}$ and $\frac{q(k)}{k}$ are both integers. But $\frac{q(k)}{k}$, $\frac{q(0)}{k}$ = -1, hence $\left\{ \frac{q(k)}{k}, \frac{q(0)}{k} \right\} = \{1, -1\}$, so $\frac{q(k)}{k} + \frac{q(0)}{k} = 0$. Hence $q(k) + q(0) = 0$, as required.

\textbf{Solution 4} (Joseph Kupka, Melbourne)

Let

\[
p(x) = a_{r}x^{r} + a_{r-1}x^{r-1} + \cdots + a_{1}x + a_{0}.
\]

Let $A = \frac{p(m)}{m-n}$, $B = -\frac{p(n)}{m-n}$. We show that $A = B$.

Now, $AB = 1$ by assumption and

\[
A + B = \frac{1}{m-n} (a_r (m^r - n^r) + \cdots + a_1 (m-n)),
\]

which is an integer, $k$ say.

We may assume w.l.o.g. that $A > 0$. Write $A = \frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b > 0$ are integers.

Then $k = A + \frac{1}{A} = \frac{a}{b} + \frac{b}{a} = \frac{a^2 + b^2}{ab}$, thus $a^2 + b^2 = kab$.

This implies that $a \mid b$ and $b \mid a$ so that $a = b$ and hence $A = 1 = B$.

\textbf{Solution 5} (Jamie Simpson, Perth)

Let

\[
p(x) = a_{r}x^{r} + a_{r-1}x^{r-1} + \cdots + a_{1}x + a_{0}
\]

and $d = m - n$. Note that

\[
p(m) - p(n) = a_r (m^r - n^r) + a_{r-1} (m^{r-1} - n^{r-1}) + \cdots + a_1 (m - n)
\]

is divisible by $d$, so $p(m) = p(n) + dX$ for some integer $X$.

Then $p^2(n)+p(n)dX = p(n)p(m) = -d^2$, which implies that $d$ divides $p(n)$.

Similarly, $d$ divides $p(m)$.

So, there exist integers $a$ and $b$ such that $p(m) = ad$ and $p(n) = bd$.

Hence $p(m)p(n) = abd^2$.

But $p(n)p(m) = -d^2$, so $ab = -1$, and $p(m) + p(n) = (a + b)d = 0$.

*Alternative 1* (Declan Gorey, year 12, Sydney Boys High School, NSW.)

We first note that if the last digit of $n$ is not $b-1$, then $S_b(n+1) = S_b(n)+1$.

1. Suppose $m|b-1$.

Let $A$ represent the digit $b-1$. Write $n = X \underbrace{AA\dots A}_{c \text{ digits}}$, where the last
digit of $X$ is not $A$.

Then

$$
\begin{align*} 
S_b(n) + 1 &= S_b(X) + c(b-1) + 1 \
&\equiv S_b(X) + 1 \pmod{m} \
&= S_b(X + 1) \
&= S_b(n + 1). 
\end{align*}
$$

2. Now suppose that whenever $m$ is a factor of $S_b(n)$, then $m$ is also a factor of $S_b(n+1)-1$.

Let $n = \underbrace{11\dots1}_{a \text{ digits}} 0A$, where $a$ is chosen so that

$$
a + b - 1 = S_b(n) \equiv 0 \pmod{m}.
$$

Then $a+1 = S_b(n+1) \equiv 1 \pmod{m}$. Hence $m|a$, whence $m|b-1$.

**Answer:** $m$ has the given property if and only if $m|b-1$.

*Alternative 2* (Tim Large, year 12, Sydney Grammar School, NSW.)

It is easy to see that $S_b(n) \equiv n \pmod{b-1}$, using the fact that $b^a \equiv 1 \pmod{b-1}$. For this reason, any divisor of $b-1$ works. Now suppose that $m$ works and consider the number $n$ whose first digit is $b-1$, whose second digit is 0, and whose remaining $m-1$ digits are $b-1$. Clearly, $S_b(n) = m(b-1)$, while $S_b(n+1)-1 = b-1$. Therefore, $m$ must be a divisor of $b-1$.

We prove this by induction.

Suppose that $n > 10$ and that $f(k) = k$ for all $k < n$.

\textbf{Case 1.} $n$ is odd, say $n = 2m + 1$.

We observe that

\[
(2m + 1)^2 + (m - 2)^2 = (2m - 1)^2 + (m + 2)^2.
\]

Now apply (1) to obtain

\[
(f(2m + 1))^2 + (f(m - 2))^2 = (f(2m - 1))^2 + (f(m + 2))^2.
\]

By induction,

\[
(f(2m + 1))^2 + (m - 2)^2 = (2m - 1)^2 + (m + 2)^2,
\]

or $f(2m + 1) = 2m + 1$.

\textbf{Case 2.} $n$ is even, say $n = 2m + 2$.

We observe that

\[
(2m + 2)^2 + (m - 4)^2 = (2m - 2)^2 + (m + 4)^2.
\]

Now apply (1) to obtain

\[
(f(2m + 2))^2 + (f(m - 4))^2 = (f(2m - 2))^2 + (f(m + 4))^2.
\]

By induction,

\[
(f(2m + 2))^2 + (m - 4)^2 = (2m - 2)^2 + (m + 4)^2,
\]

or $f(2m + 2) = 2m + 2$.

This confirms our suspicion, and so the answer is:

The only function $f$ satisfying the condition of the problem is given by
$f(x) = x$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^3 - 30x^2 + rx - 780 &= (x-a)(x-b)(x-c) \\
&= x^3 - (a+b+c)x^2 + (ab+ac+bc)x - abc,
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
30 = a + b + c, \tag{1}
$$

$$
r = ab + ac + bc, \tag{2}
$$

$$
780 = abc. \tag{3}
$$

By (1), we have

$$
(a+b)^2 = (30-c)^2,
$$

while, by Pythagoras,

$$
c^2 = a^2 + b^2,
$$

so that

$$
0 = 900 - 60c - 2ab.
$$

Hence, since $ab = \frac{780}{c}$ by (3), this simplifies to

$$
c^2 - 15c + 26 = 0,
$$

implying that either $c = 2$ or $c = 13$.

If $c = 2$, then $0 < a, b < 2$ and $a + b + c \ne 30$.

If, however, $c = 13$, then, by (3), $ab = 60$ while, by (1), $a+b=17$ so that $a, b$ are roots of the quadratic $x^2 - 17x + 60 = 0$. Hence $(a,b) = (5,12)$ or $(12,5)$. Therefore, by (2), $r = ab + ac + bc = 60 + 65 + 156 = 281$.

Conversely, one verifies immediately, that 5, 12, 13 are the solutions of the equation $x^3 - 30x^2 + 281x - 780 = 0$.

*Alternative 1* (Colin Lu, year 12, Melbourne Grammar School, VIC.)

The question is equivalent to finding all $n$ such that $\frac{i(i-1)}{2}$ takes every value modulo $n$.

Suppose that an odd prime $p$ divides $n$. Then $\frac{i(i-1)}{2}$ takes every value modulo $p$. If we set $a_k = \frac{k(k-1)}{2}$, then the sequence $a_1, a_2, \dots$ is periodic modulo $p$ with period $p$. Hence $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_p$ must be distinct modulo $p$. But this is simply not true, because $a_1 \equiv 0 \equiv a_p \pmod{p}$.

Thus we are left only with the case when $n$ is a power of 2. We want to show that $\frac{i(i-1)}{2}$ takes all values modulo $2^k$ for $k = 0, 1, 2, \dots$. This is the same as showing that $i(i-1)$ takes all even values modulo $2^{k+1}$. We claim that as $i$ goes from 1 to $2^k$, all these even values are taken exactly once. Suppose to the contrary that

$$
a(a-1) \equiv b(b-1) \pmod{2^{k+1}}
$$

for some $a, b$ where $1 \le a < b \le 2^k$. This may be rearranged as

$$
(a+b-1)(a-b) \equiv 0 \pmod{2^{k+1}}.
$$

*Alternative 2* (Ivan Guo, Sydney)

Consider the following 201 disjoint sets:

(201, 2211)
(200, 2200)
...
(20, 220)
(19, 209)
(18, 221, 401 = 18 \times 10 + 221)
(17, 219, 2207 = 219 \times 10 + 17)
(16, 218, 2196 = 218 \times 10 + 16)
...
(8, 210, 2108)
(7, 208, 2087)
...
(1, 202, 2021)

At least one of those sets must be in $T$.

*Alternative 3* (Declan Gorey, year 12, Sydney Boys High School, NSW.)

Let $k$ be the smallest element of $T$.

If $k \ge 201$, the $T = \{201, 202, \dots, 2211\}$ and $11 \times 201 = 2211$.

If $20 \le k \le 200$, consider the following $212 - k$ sets

\[
\{i, i + 10k\} \text{ for } i = k, k + 1, \dots, 211.
\]

They are disjoint because $211 < 11k$ and they are subsets of $S$ because $211 + 10k \le 2211$. If each of these sets contained an element not in $T$, then this would yield $212 - k$ elements greater than or equal to $k$ which are not in $T$. However, since $k$ is the smallest element of $T$, there are $k-1$ numbers below $k$ which are also not in $T$. Hence there are a total of 211 numbers which are not in $T$. This contradicts that $S \setminus T$ has 200 elements. Thus at least one of these sets is entirely in $T$. Thus $i + 10k = i + 10 \times k$ can be entirely fulfilled within $T$.

If $1 \le k \le 19$, divide the $2011 - k$ elements of $S$ which are at least $k$ into blocks of $20k$ consecutive elements. Each block has the form $(a+1, a+2, \dots, a+20k)$. If there is no desired 11-tuple in $T$, then since $a+i+10k = (a+i)+10 \times k$, at most one member of the pair $(a+i, a+i+10k)$ can be in $T$ for each $i$. Thus each block of $20k$ eliminates at least $10k$ members from $T$. Hence we eliminate at least $f(k) = \lfloor \frac{2011-k}{20k} \rfloor \times 10k$ elements from being in $T$. But $f(k) > (\frac{2011-k}{20k} - 1) \times 10k = \frac{1}{2}(2011 - 21k) \ge \frac{1}{2}(2011 - 21 \times 19) = 806$. Thus $T$ would have far too few elements, a contradiction.

*Alternative 4* (Tim Large, year 12, Sydney Grammar School, NSW.)

Suppose to the contrary that there exists such a set $T$ such that no element of $T$ is the sum of 11 elements of $T$. Let $m$ be the maximal element of $T$. Note that since $|T| = 2011$, we have $m \ge 2011$. Thus there are $m - 2011$ elements of $\{1, 2, \dots, m\}$ which are in $S \setminus T \dots (*)$.

For $i = 1, 2, \dots, \lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor$, let $H_i = \{i, m - 10i\}$. N.B. if $i = \frac{m}{11}$ then we set $H_{\frac{m}{11}} = \{\frac{m}{11}\}$. The $H_i$ are disjoint because $1 < 2 < \dots < \lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor \le m - 10 \lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor < m - 10 (\lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor - 1) < \dots < m - 10$. Furthermore, if $H_i \subseteq T$ for some $i$, then since $10 \times i + (m - 10i) = m$ we have a contradiction to the assumption that $m$ is not a sum of 11 elements of $T$.

Thus each $H_i$ contains an element not in $T$. This gives a total of at least $\lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor$ elements in $S \setminus T$ each of which is at most $m - 10$. By our earlier observation (*), we deduce that $m - 2011 \ge \lfloor \frac{m}{11} \rfloor > \frac{m}{11} - 1$. This implies that $m > 2211$, a contradiction.

*Alternative 5* (Jury)

Of the numbers in $T$ let $t$ be the smallest. Note that $t \le 201$.

For each $i$ with $0 \le i \le 2211 - 11t$, consider the sum of the following 11 elements of $T$ all of which are greater than or equal to $t$:

$t, t, \dots, t(10 \text{ times}), t + i.$

These sums, $11t + i$, are of course in $S$.

It thus suffices to prove that there is at least one $i$ with $0 \le i \le 2211 - 11t$, for which both $t + i$ and $11t + i$ are in $T$.

There are exactly $2211 - (t - 1) - 2011 = 201 - t$ numbers in $S$ that are greater than $t$ and are not in $T$. Hence there are at most $201 - t$ values of $i$ for which $t + i$ is not in $T$.

Likewise, there are at most $201 - t$ values of $i$ for which $11t + i$ is not in $T$. So, there are at most $2(201 - t) = 402 - 2t$ values of $i$ for which either $t + i$ or $11t + i$ (or both) is not in $T$. It follows that there are at least

\[
(2211 - 11t + 1) - (402 - 2t) = 1810 - 9t
\]

values of $i$ for which both $t + i$ and $11t + i$ are in $T$. Since $t \le 201$, we have $1810 - 9t \ge 1$, q.e.d.

*Alternative 1* (Declan Gorey, year 12, Sydney Boys High School, NSW.)

Since the question is completely symmetric in $a, b, c$, we may assume without loss of generality that $a \ge b \ge c$. Then,

$$
a^2 < a^2 + b + c \le a^2 + a + a < a^2 + 2a + 1 = (a + 1)^2.
$$

Thus

$$
a < \sqrt{a^2 + b + c} < a + 1.
$$

Therefore, $\sqrt{a^2 + b + c}$ cannot be an integer because it lies between two consecutive integers. Hence $a^2 + b + c$ cannot be a perfect square.

*Alternative 2* (Patrick He, year 10, Scotch College, VIC.)

Since $a, b, c > 0$ we have $a^2 + b + c > a^2$. If $a^2 + b + c$ is a perfect square, then $a^2 + b + c \ge (a+1)^2 = a^2 + 2a + 1$. Thus $b + c \ge 2a + 1$.

Similarly, if $b^2+c+a$ and $c^2+a+b$ are also perfect squares, then $c+a \ge 2b+1$ and $a+b \ge 2c+1$. Adding the three inequalities gives

$$
2a + 2b + 2c \ge 2a + 2b + 2c + 3,
$$

which is a contradiction. Thus the three given expressions cannot all be perfect squares.

Put $x = y = 1$ to find $f(f(1)) = f(1)$. Next put $x = 1$ and $y = f(1)$ and use $f(f(1)) = f(1)$ to find $f(1)^2 = f(1)$. Thus $f(1) = 0$ or $f(1) = 1$. If $f(1) = 1$, then put $y = 1$ to find $f(x) = x$ for all $x$, however this contradicts condition (1). Therefore, we must have $f(1) = 0$.

Substitute $x = 1$ and use $f(1) = 0$ to find $f(f(y)) = 2f(y)$ for all $y$. This means that if a number $t$ belongs to the range of the function $f$, then so does $2t$, and by induction so does $2^nt$ for any non-negative integer $n$. So, if there is a real number $a$ such that $f(a) > 0$, then $2^nf(a)$ belongs to the range of $f$ for any real number $n$. But this leads to a contradiction of condition (1). Thus we must have

\[
f(x) \le 0 \text{ for all } x \in \mathbb{R}.
\]

By substituting $\frac{x}{2}$ for $x$ and $f(y)$ for $y$ and using $f(f(y)) = 2f(y)$, we obtain

\[
\begin{aligned} & f(xf(y)) + f(y)f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right) = xf(y) + f\left(\frac{x}{2}f(y)\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad & xf(y) - f(xf(y)) = f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)f(y) - f\left(\frac{x}{2}f(y)\right) \\ & \ge 0, \end{aligned}
\]

where the last line of the above is true because the values of $f$ are non-positive. Combining this with condition (2) we find that

\[
yf(x) \ge f(xy)
\]

If we set $x > 0$ and $y = \frac{1}{x}$ in the above inequality and use the fact that $f(1) = 0$, we find that $f(x) \ge 0$. Also by putting $x = 0$ and $y = 2$ into the above inequality we find that $f(0) \ge 0$. However, since $f(x) \le 0$ for all $x$, we conclude that

\[
f(x) = 0 \quad \text{for all } x \ge 0.
\]

If $f(x) = 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, then clearly this function is one solution to the problem.

If, on the other hand, there exists $b \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(b) \ne 0$, then by our conclusions above we have $b < 0$ and $f(b) < 0$. Next put $c = f(b)$ to find $f(c) = f(f(b)) = 2f(b) = 2c$. \[

\]

from which it follows that $f(x) = 2x$ for any negative real number $x$.

Hence we have found that the function

\[
f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } x \ge 0 \\ 2x & \text{if } x < 0 \end{cases}
\]

is the only other potential solution to the problem. Since it is very non-obvious as to whether or not this is a solution, a check is absolutely vital.

This function satisfies condition (1) because $f(x) \le 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

We check the satisfaction of condition (2) by separating into 4 cases depending on whether $x$ or $y$ are negative or not.

* For $x, y \ge 0$, both sides of (2) are 0.

* For $x < 0$ and $y \ge 0$, we have $xy \le 0$ and both sides of (2) are equal to $2xy$.

* For $x, y < 0$, we have $xy > 0$ and both sides of (2) are $2xy$.

*Alternative 1* (Declan Gorey, year 12, Sydney Boys High School, NSW. Declan was a silver medalist with the 2011 Australian IMO Team.)

Without loss of generality we may assume $a_1 < a_2 < a_3 < a_4$. Then

$$
a_3 + a_4 > a_1 + a_2 \quad \text{and} \quad a_2 + a_4 > a_1 + a_3.
$$

Because $a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4 = s_A$, these imply that

$$
s_A > a_3 + a_4 > \frac{s_A}{2} \quad \text{and} \quad s_A > a_2 + a_4 > \frac{s_A}{2}.
$$

Thus $a_3 + a_4 \nmid s_A$ and $a_2 + a_4 \nmid s_A$. Since there are six possible pairs $a_i + a_j$ ($1 \le i < j \le 4$) his implies that $n_A \le 4$. Furthermore, $n_A = 4$ is achieved with the quadruple $(a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4) = (1, 5, 7, 11)$. Thus the maximum value for $n_A$ is $n_A = 4$.

The rest of the problem consists of finding all quadruples $(a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4)$ with $a_1 < a_2 < a_3 < a_4$, such that $s_A$ is divisible by the four quantities $a_1 + a_2, a_1 + a_3, a_1 + a_4$ and $a_2 + a_3$.

Since $a_2 + a_3 \le \frac{s_A}{2}$ and $a_1 + a_4 \le \frac{s_A}{2}$, adding these two inequalities yields $a_2 + a_3 + a_1 + a_4 \le s_A$, with equality if and only if the first two inequalities are both equalities. But because we are given that $a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4 = s_A$, we must have

$$
a_2 + a_3 = a_1 + a_4 = \frac{s_A}{2}.
$$

From this and using $a_2 < a_3$ it follows that $a_3 > \frac{s_A}{4}$. Thus $a_1 + a_3 > \frac{s_A}{4}$. Furthermore since $a_1 + a_3 < a_2 + a_4$ and $a_1 + a_2 + a_2 + a_4 = s_A$, we have $a_1 + a_3 < \frac{s_A}{2}$. Thus we have $\frac{s_A}{4} < a_1 + a_3 < \frac{s_A}{2}$, from which it follows that

$$
a_1 + a_3 = \frac{s_A}{3}.
$$

Additionally since $a_1 + a_2$ is a divisor of $s_A$, there is a positive integer $k$ such that

$$
a_1 + a_2 = \frac{s_A}{k}.
$$

Hence, in summary, we have

$$
s_A = 2(a_2 + a_3) = 2(a_1 + a_4) = 3(a_1 + a_3) = k(a_1 + a_2) \quad (*)
$$

where $k$ is a positive integer.

2011.statement_latex: Given any set $A = \{a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4\}$ of four distinct positive integers, we denote the sum $a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4$ by $s_A$. Let $n_A$ denote the number of pairs $(i, j)$ with $1 \le i < j \le 4$ for which $a_i + a_j$ divides $s_A$. Find all sets $A$ of four distinct positive integers which achieve the largest possible value of $n_A$.

From $2(a_2 + a_3) = 3(a_1 + a_3)$ we derive $a_3 = 2a_2 - 3a_1$. Substituting this into $s_A = 3(a_1 + a_3)$ yields $s_A = 6(a_2 - a_1)$. Thus $k(a_1 + a_2) = 6(a_2 - a_1)$ is true by using (*). This rearranges to

$$
\frac{a_2}{a_1} = \frac{6+k}{6-k} \quad (\text{**}).
$$

Note this implies that $k \neq 6$ because $\frac{a_2}{a_1}$ is a well defined real number. Going back to $a_3 = 2a_2 - 3a_1$ and using $a_3 > a_2$, we find $2a_2 - 3a_1 > a_2$, and so

$$
\frac{a_2}{a_1} > 3.
$$

Hence comparing the two above displayed equations we deduce

$$
\frac{6+k}{6-k} > 3.
$$

Note that this inequality is false for $k > 6$ and for $k < 6$ it easily implies $k > 3$. Since we earlier observed that $k \neq 6$ it only remains to investigate the cases $k = 4$ and $k = 5$.

If $k = 4$, we use (**) to find $a_2 = 5a_1$, and then use (*) to find $a_3 = 7a_1$ and $a_4 = 11a_1$.

If $k = 5$, we use (**) to find $a_2 = 11a_1$, and then use (*) to find $a_3 = 19a_1$ and $a_4 = 29a_1$.

Hence the only possible solutions to the problem are

$$
(a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4) = (t, 5t, 7t, 11t) \text{ or } (t, 11t, 19t, 29t)
$$

and any permutation of these where $t$ is a positive integer.

It is straightforward to verify that these are indeed valid solutions.

The proof that $n_A = 4$ is the maximal value of $n_A$ is similar to that in the first alternative. And as in the first alternative the rest of the problem consists of finding all quadruples $(a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4)$ with $a_1 < a_2 < a_3 < a_4$, such that $a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4$ is divisible by $a_1 + a_2, a_1 + a_3, a_1 + a_4$ and $a_2 + a_3$.

Note that $a_1 + a_4|a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4 \Rightarrow a_1 + a_4|a_2 + a_3 \Rightarrow a_1 + a_4 \le a_2 + a_3$. Similarly, $a_2 + a_3|a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + a_4 \Rightarrow a_2 + a_3|a_1 + a_4 \Rightarrow a_2 + a_3 \le a_1 + a_4$. Hence it follows that $a_1 + a_4 = a_2 + a_3$ and so,

$$
s_A = 2(a_2 + a_3).
$$

Since $a_1 + a_2|s_A$ and $a_1 + a_3|s_A$ there are $x, y \in \mathbb{N}^+$ such that

$$
x(a_1 + a_2) = y(a_1 + a_3) = 2(a_2 + a_3).
$$

Thus $x(a_1+a_2) = 2(a_2+a_3) > 2(a_1+a_2)$ from which we deduce that $x > 2$. Similarly, $y(a_1+a_3) = 2(a_2+a_3) > 2(a_1+a_3)$ implying that $y > 2$. Since $x, y$ are positive integers we thus have

$$
x, y \geq 3.
$$

Also we have $x(a_1 + a_2) = y(a_1 + a_3) > y(a_1 + a_2)$ from which we deduce $x > y$ and so

$$
x \geq y + 1 \geq 4.
$$

If $y \geq 4$, then also $x \geq 5$. Thus $2(a_2 + a_3) = x(a_1 + a_2) > 4(a_1 + a_2)$ and $2(a_2 + a_3) = y(a_1 + a_3) \geq 4(a_1 + a_3)$ and then summing these two inequalities we find $4(a_2 + a_3) > 8a_1 + 4a_2 + 4a_3$, which is obviously false. Thus $y < 4$. Since $y \geq 3$ and $y \in \mathbb{N}^+$ it follows that $y = 3$. Hence we have

$$
x(a_1 + a_2) = 3(a_1 + a_3) = 2(a_2 + a_3).
$$

Then $3(a_1 + a_3) = 2(a_2 + a_3)$ yields

$$
a_3 = 2a_2 - 3a_1.
$$

Substitute this into $x(a_1 + a_2) = 2(a_2 + a_3)$ to find

$$
x(a_1 + a_2) = 6(a_2 - a_1) < 6(a_2 + a_1).
$$

Hence $x < 6$. However, since $x \geq 4$, this implies that $x = 4$ or $x = 5$.

If $x = 4$ then $4(a_1 + a_2) = 6(a_2 - a_1)$ from which $a_2 = 5a_1$. Then also $a_3 = 2a_2 - 3a_1 = 7a_1$ and $a_4 = a_2 + a_3 - a_1 = 11a_1$.

If $x = 5$ a similar procedure yields $a_2 = 11a_1$, $a_3 = 19a_1$ and $a_4 = 29a_1$.

Thus the set of solutions to $n_A = 4$ is given by $A = \{t, 5t, 7t, 117\}$ or $A = \{t, 11t, 19t, 29t\}$. It is easy to verify that these work.

**Lemma 2.** As the windmill proceeds, the number of points on the positive side of $\ell$ stays the same after each pivot transfer.

*Proof.* To see this, suppose at some time the line $\ell$ passes through a single point $T \in S$ but is also about to pass through $U \in S$ as the windmill proceeds, making $U$ the new pivot. If $U$ is on the negative side of $\ell$, then as the windmill proceeds, $\ell$ passes through both $T$ and $U$. Then, because $U$ is the new pivot, as the windmill continues $T$ is now on the negative side of $\ell$. Thus the negative side of $\ell$ has lost the single point $U$, but gained the single point $T$. Hence the number of points on the negative side of $\ell$ stays the same, and thus the number of points on the positive side of $\ell$ also stays the same. A similar argument holds if $U$ is on the positive side of $\ell$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2011_p145_data_6a19a38eb1.png)

**Lemma 3.** If the oriented line $\ell$ is a halving line for its initial pivot, then $\ell$ will always be a halving line for any later pivot.

*Proof.* This is an immediate consequence of lemma 2.

Back to the problem. We claim that the windmill defined by an arbitrary point $P$ and an oriented halving line $\ell$ through $P$ visits every point in $S$ as a pivot infinitely many times. To prove this let $X$ be any point in $S$. From lemma 1 there exists an oriented halving line, $\mu$ say, through $X$. If $\mu$ is unlucky enough to be parallel to any line joining two other points of $S$, perturb $\mu$ slightly by rotating it about $X$ by a tiny amount so that $\mu$ is still a halving line but is no longer parallel to any of these other lines. Now as the oriented line $\ell$ continues to rotate, it finds itself parallel to $\mu$ and in the same orientation as $\mu$ infinitely often. Note that at this point we have arranged it so that $\ell$ passes through a single point, $Y$ say, of $S$. If $Y \neq X$, then it is not possible for both $\ell$ and $\mu$ to be halving lines. This is because a parallel translation of an oriented line would disturb the halving property. But this is in contradiction to lemma 3.

Thus $Y = X$ and so the point $X$ is visited infinitely often.

Let $S$ contain $m$ points.

We define the notion of an oriented line $\ell$ as well as the positive and negative side of an oriented line. An oriented line is an ordinary line along with a given orientation. The orientation is in the direction of a fixed vector which is parallel to the line. Note that a line has only two possible orientations. Furthermore, the line divides the plane into two half planes. If $A$ and $B$ are two different points on the line, and ray $\overrightarrow{AB}$ is pointing in the direction of the orientation of the line, then rotation of the ray $\overrightarrow{AB}$ anticlockwise $180^\circ$ about $A$ sweeps out a half plane. This half plane is said to be the *positive* side of the oriented line $\ell$. The other side is called the *negative* side of $\ell$.

% IMAGE: ![](images/Australian_Scene_2011_p144_data_9af1140bcd.png)

**Lemma 1.** For any point $P \in S$ there exists an oriented line $\ell$ through $P$ which contains no other point of $S$ and divides the remaining $m-1$ points of $S$ as closely into to halves as possible. Specifically, if $m = 2n + 1$ is odd, there are exactly $n$ points on each side of $\ell$. But if $m = 2n$ is even, there are exactly $n$ points on the positive side of $\ell$ and $n-1$ points on the negative side of $\ell$. (We shall call such an oriented line a *halving* oriented line.)

*Proof.* We cover both cases $m = 2n+1$ and $m = 2n$ simultaneously. Suppose we rotate the oriented line $\ell$ by $180^\circ$ slowly about $P$ and at the same time letting the positive and negative half planes rotate with $\ell$. (Note that this is an ordinary rotation, not a windmill process.) For any angle $\theta$ of partial rotation ($0 \le \theta \le 180^\circ$), let $f(\theta)$ be the number of points of $S$ lying on the positive side of $\ell$. If $f(0^\circ) = n$ then we are done. Otherwise we may suppose without loss of generality that $f(0^\circ) = n+r$ where $r$ is an integer. If $r > 0$ then $f(180^\circ) = m - 1 - n - r < n$ because all the points on the negative side of $\ell$ at the beginning are now on the positive side of $\ell$ at the end. Note also that the value of $f$ is always a positive integer and that it changes by at most 1 as the line rotates. Since $f(0^\circ) > n$ and $f(180^\circ) < n$, by the Discrete Intermediate Value Theorem (DIVT) there is a value of $\theta$ such that $f(\theta) = n$. Hence there is a stage where the oriented line $\ell$ has become a halving line. A similar argument using the DIVT holds for the case $r < 0$ because in this case $f(0^\circ) < n$ and $f(180^\circ) = m - 1 - n - r \ge n$.

*Alternative 1* (Tim Large, year 12, Sydney Grammar School, NSW. Tim was a silver medalist with the 2011 Australian IMO Team.)

For each positive integer $n$, let $A_n$ be the number of ways to place the $n$ weights as required. Observe that $A_1 = 1$ because the $2^0$ weight can only be placed on the left balance.

**Lemma.** Suppose that there are some weights on one side of the balance and some on the other side. Then whichever side contains the heaviest individual weight is also the heaviest side.

*Proof.* Suppose that the heaviest weight is $2^h$. Then the weights on the other side of the balance are a subset of $\{2^0, 2^1, \dots, 2^{h-1}\}$. Thus the other side of the balance has total weight at most $2^0+2^1+\dots+2^{h-1} = 2^h-1 < 2^h$. Back to the problem. Consider what happens if we remove the $2^0$ weight from consideration. Since the remaining weights are $2 \times 2^0, 2 \times 2^1, \dots, 2 \times 2^{n-2}$, they may be placed in $A_{n-1}$ ways.

Now insert the $2^0$ weight. By the lemma it only matters that the heaviest weight is on the left balance at each stage. Thus if the $2^0$ weight is placed first, it is the heaviest weight and must go on the left balance. Otherwise, for the remaining $n-1$ possible places to insert the $2^0$ weight it is not the heaviest weight at its stage of insertion. Thus by the lemma it can go either side of the balance without violating the conditions. Hence there are a total of $1+2(n-1)$ possible ways to insert the $2^0$ weight. Hence

$$
A_n = (2n - 1)A_{n-1}.
$$

We now unpeel this recurrence to find $A_n = (2n-1) \cdot (2n-3) \cdots 3 \cdot 1$.

*Alternative 2* (Nancy Fu, year 11, James Ruse Agricultural High School, NSW. Nancy was a bronze medalist with the 2011 Australian IMO Team.)

It is possible to generalize the problem to cover the more general situation for weights $w_1, w_2, \dots, w_n$ where $w_i > w_1 + w_2 + \dots + w_{i-1}$ for all positive integers $i$ with $2 \le i \le n$. (Note that the given problem is the special case where $w_j = 2^{j-1}$ for $j = 1, 2, \dots, n$.)

As in the first alternative, let $A_n$ be the number of ways to place the $n$ weights as required.

**Lemma.** Suppose that there are some weights on one side of the balance and some on the other side. Then whichever side contains the heaviest individual weight is also the heaviest side.

*Proof.* The proof of this is very similar to that found in the first alternative except we are using $w_i$ instead of $2^{i-1}$ for $i = 1, 2, \dots, n$.

Returning to the problem. Consider the placement of the heaviest weight $w_n$ where $n > 1$. Suppose that for a fixed positive integer $i$, $(0 \le i \le n-1)$, $i$ weights are placed after it and $n - (i + 1)$ weights are placed before it.

$$
\underbrace{\dots\dots\dots\dots\dots}_{n-(i+1)} w_n \underbrace{\dots\dots\dots\dots\dots}_{i}
$$

There are $\binom{n-1}{i}$ of choosing which $i$ weights come after $w_n$. Using the lemma, since the largest weight $w_n$, has already been placed, these $i$ weights can be placed in any order, of which there are $i!$ orders, and on either side of the balance, of which there are $2^i$ ways of choosing sides for the $i$ weights. Hence, altogether, there are $\binom{n-1}{i} \cdot i! \cdot 2^i$ ways of choosing and placing $i$ weights after $w_n$. For the remaining $n - (i + 1)$ weights before $w_n$ there are $A_{n-(i+1)}$ ways of placing these. Thus the total number of ways of placing $i$ weights after $w_n$ and $n - (i + 1)$ weights before $w_n$ is equal to

$$
A_{n-(i+1)} \cdot 2^i \cdot \frac{(n-1)!}{(n-(i+1))!}
$$

Since $i$ may be any integer in the range $0 \le i \le n-1$, we have the following formula which we manipulate.

$$
\begin{align*}
A_n &= \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} A_{n-(i+1)} \cdot 2^i \cdot \frac{(n-1)!}{(n-(i+1))!} \\
&= A_{n-1} + \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} A_{n-(i+1)} \cdot 2^i \cdot \frac{(n-1)!}{(n-(i+1))!} \\
&= A_{n-1} + 2(n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} A_{n-(i+1)} \cdot 2^{i-1} \cdot \frac{(n-2)!}{(n-(i+1))!} \\
&= A_{n-1} + 2(n-1) \sum_{j=0}^{n-2} A_{n-1-(j+1)} \cdot 2^j \cdot \frac{(n-2)!}{(n-1-(j+1))!} \\
&= A_{n-1} + 2(n-1)A_{n-1}.
\end{align*}
$$

Thus we have $A_n = (2n-1)A_{n-1}$ (*).

We claim that $A_n = (2n-1)(2n-3)\dots\cdot 3 \cdot 1$. We prove this by induction.

The base step $A_1 = 1$ is true because a single weight must go on the left balance.

For the inductive step we have $A_{n+1} = (2n+1)A_n$ from (*). Then, using the inductive assumption we derive $A_{n+1} = (2n+1)(2n-1)(2n-3)\dots\cdot 3 \cdot 1$, as desired. This concludes the induction and the proof.

Alternative 1 (Yanning Xu, year 11, St Peters College, SA. Yanning was a silver medalist with the 2011 Australian IMO Team.)

For reference we write down the given property recalling that $f: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{N}^+$.

$$
f(m-n)|f(m)-f(n) \quad (1)
$$

Putting $n = 0$ tells us that $f(m)|f(m) - f(0)$. Thus we derive the following two properties.

$$
f(m)|f(0) \text{ for all } m \in \mathbb{Z} \quad (2)
$$

$$
\{f(m) : m \in \mathbb{Z}\} \text{ is finite} \quad (3)
$$

Put $m = 0$ in (1) to find $f(-n)|f(0) - f(n)$. From (2) $f(-n)|f(0)$, hence we conclude $f(-n)|f(n)$. Replacing $n$ with $-n$ we also have $f(n)|f(-n)$. These imply that

$$
f(n) = f(-n) \text{ for all } n \in \mathbb{Z} \quad (4).
$$

From (2) let $b_1 < b_2 < \dots < b_k$ be the set of values written out in increasing order that $f(m)$ takes as $m$ ranges over all integers. We want to prove $b_i|b_j$ for all integers $1 \le i < j \le k$. It suffices to show $b_i|b_{i+1}$ for $i = 1, 2, \dots, k$.

From (1) we have $f(a_{i+1} - a_i)|b_{i+1} - b_i < b_{i+1}$. Since $f(a_{i+1} - a_i)$ is in the range of $f$ we must have $f(a_{i+1} - a_i) = b_j$ for some positive integer $j \le i$. Hence

$$
b_j|b_{i+1} - b_i.
$$

If $j = i$ then $b_i|b_{i+1} - b_i$ from which $b_i|b_{i+1}$, as desired.

If on the other hand $j < i$ then put $m = a_i - a_{i+1}$ and $n = a_i$ into (1) to find $f(-a_{i+1})|f(a_i - a_{i+1}) - b_i$. Then, using (4) this implies $b_{i+1}|b_i - b_j$. But $0 < b_i - b_j < b_i$. Thus $b_{i+1} < b_i$, a contradiction. Hence this case does not occur. This concludes the proof.

Alternative 2 (Colin Lu, year 12, Melbourne Grammar School, VIC. Colin was a Bronze medalist with the 2011 Australian IMO Team.)

As in the first alternative we prove that $f$ is an even function, that is, $f(x) = f(-x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $f(x)|f(0)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{Z}$. Thus $f$ is bounded.

Assume for the sake of contradiction that it is possible to find $a, b$ in the range of $f$ with $a < b$ but $a \nmid b$. Since $0 < a < b$ we also have $b \nmid a$. Call such a pair $(a, b)$ exceptional. Since $f$ is bounded we may assume additionally that of all possible exceptional pairs, we have chosen one for which $a + b$ is maximal.

Let $x, y$ be such that $f(x) = a$ and $f(y) = b$. Putting $m = y - x$ and $n = y$ into the original property yields $f(-x)|f(y-x) - f(y)$. Since $f$ is even this implies

$$
a|c - b.
$$

Similarly, we have

$$
b|c - a,
$$

where $c = f(y - x) = f(x - y)$.

Since $a \nmid b$ then from $a|c - b$, we must have also $a \nmid c$. Similarly, since $b \nmid a$ then from $b|c - a$, we must also have $b \nmid c$. Thus $c \neq a, b$

If $c > b$ were true, then also $c > a$ from $b > a$. But then we would have $c$ is in the range of $f$ with $b < c$ and with $b \nmid c$. However, since $b + c > a + b$, this would contradict the maximality of $a + b$.

If $c < a$ were true, then from $b|c - a$ we would have $b|a - c$, so that $b < a$, a contradiction.

The final possibility is if $a < c < b$ were true. Then from $b|c - a$ we would have $b < c < b$, a contradiction.

Hence our assumption always leads to a contradiction. Thus there are no exceptional pairs, as required.
